sentences.original: êyakô sâkahikan êh-misâk, nimitaw isi wîkiwak opwâsimôwak, êkotah êh-mihcêticik.
sentences.text: êwako sâkahikan ê-misâk nimitaw isi wîkiwak opwâsîmôwak êkota ê-mihcêticik
sentences.english: To the south of that great lake dwelt some Assiniboine, and they were many.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê pêyak awa nâpêw ocawâsimisah âhkosiyiwa.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê pêyak awa nâpêw ocawâsimisa âhkosiyiwa
sentences.english: Then at one time a certain man's child fell sick.

sentences.original: hâtah êh-atoskêmot, êh-nanâtawihimiht, êh-tipahikâkêt otêmah mîna wîkiwâw mîna otayôwinisiwâwa, tahkih mistah âhkosiyiwa.
sentences.text: âta ê-atoskêmot ê-nanâtawihimiht ê-tipahikâkêt otêma mîna wîkiwâw mîna otayiwinisiwâwa tahki mistahi âhkosiyiwa
sentences.english: Although he employed medicine-men to have the child doctored, and paid out his horse and his tent and his clothes, yet the child remained very sick.
At last he had spent all his belongings;

sentences.original: mîna pâskisikan mêkiw, pitanê pimâtisit ntawâsimis! êh-itêyihtah.
sentences.english: he gave also his gun, thinking, “Would that my child might live!”
But they could not get the child well.
Finally that child died.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah kitimâkisiw awa nâpêw mîn âw îskwêw, pisisik êh-mâtocik, ê-mawîhkâtâcik otawâsimisiwâwa, piyisk kinwêsk.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa kitimâkisiw awa nâpêw mîna awa iskwêw pisisik ê-mâtocik ê-mawîhkâtâcik otawâsimisiwâwa piyisk kinwêsk
sentences.english: And so then that man and woman were poor, and they were always weeping, lamenting their child, for a long time.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kîksêpâ êh-wâpahtahk ê-wîh-wâpaniyik, sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw, nikwatis nika-papâ-ma-mâton, êy-itêyihtah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kîkisêpâ ê-wâpahtahk ê-wî-wâpaniyik sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw ê-itêyihtah
sentences.english: Then early one morning, when he saw that day was at hand, that man went off, thinking, “Off by myself somewhere I shall go about and weep.”
He went away, wrapping himself in a buffalo hide, without his inner garments.

sentences.original: nama kêkway oskotâkay; nama kêkway otâsah; pikoh otâsiyânah, êkwah omaskisinah, êkwah ocâhpîhcisah, êkot ê-asiwatêyik êkotah môhkomân êh-apisâsiniyik.
sentences.text: nama kêkway oskotâkay nama kêkway otâsa piko otâsiyâna êkwa omaskisina êkwa ocahpihcisa êkota ê-asiwatêyik êkota môhkomân ê-apisâsiniyik
sentences.english: He wore no coat; no leggings; he had only his breechcloth and his moccasins, and his pouch, which contained a small knife.

sentences.original: êkos îsi sipwêhtêw aw ôpwâsimôw, ê-sîkâwit.
sentences.text: êkosi isi sipwêhtêw awa opwâsîmôw ê-sîkâwit
sentences.english: In this guise the Assiniboine set out, because he was in mourning.
When he had gone a ways, he wept as he went on.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-pa-pimohtêt, ôma kâ-misâk sâkahikan êkotah sisonêh êh-pimi-ma-mâtot, piyisk wâhyawês ayâw.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-pa-pimohtêt ôma kâ-misâk sâkahikan êkota sisonê ê-pimi-ma-mâtot piyisk wâhyawês ayâw
sentences.english: And, as he walked along, weeping by the shore of that big lake, at last he had gone quite far.
He could no longer see the tipis.

sentences.original: êkwah pôni-mâtôw, êh-ây-ispatinâyik êkotah êh-itohtêt, êkotê ispatinâhk nik-ây-apin, êh-itêyihtah.
sentences.text: êkwa pôni-mâtôw ê-ay-ispatinâyik êkota ê-itohtêt ê-itêyihtah
sentences.english: Then he ceased weeping, and went to where there were some hills, thinking, “There on a hilltop I shall sit.”

sentences.original: pîhtaw êy-astâhikot ayîsiyiniwah, êkwah ê-ntawâpamikot, kiyâm wâpamitwâwi ayahciyiniwak, nika-nipahikok, iyikohk kâ-mihtâtak ncawâsimis, êh-itêyihtah.
sentences.text: pîhtaw ê-astâhikot ayîsiyiniwa êkwa ê-nitawâpamikot ê-itêyihtah
sentences.english: Now that he had come here, he began to be frightened by the thought of Blackfoot, who might come and see him, but he thought, “If the Blackfoot see me, let them kill me, so much do I grieve for my child.”

sentences.original: êyakô ê-wîh-at-âmaciwêt, namoya mistah ê-ispatinâyik, awas-itah kotak mistahi ispatinâyiw, êkotah kâ-wâpamât, ôm itêh k-ôh-ayât ohci, êh-at-âmaciwêyit ayîsiyiniwah, wâpowêyân ê-kikasâkêyit, pâskisikan êh-tahkonamiyit, êh-ati-nîpawiyit mâna, ê-nanâtawâpiyit.
sentences.text: êwako ê-wî-ati-âmaciwêt namôya mistahi ê-ispatinâyik awasita kotak mistahi ispatinâyiw êkota kâ-wâpamât ôma itê kâ-ôh-ayât ohci ê-ati-âmaciwêyit ayîsiyiniwa wâpowêyân ê-kikasâkêyit pâskisikan ê-tahkonamiyit ê-ati-nîpawiyit mâna ê-nanâtawâpiyit
sentences.english: As he was on the way, climbing a smaller hill, there rose beyond it another very high one, and there he saw, from the place he had reached, a man climbing up, a man wearing a blanket-robe and holding a gun, who stood still every little ways to reconnoitre.
Then he, in his turn, kept watching the other.
The other did not see him.
At last, when the other had nearly reached the top of his hill, he squatted down and went on, crawling.

sentences.original: êh-kîs-âmaciwêyit, êkotah pimisiniyiwa, kâ-wâpamât itâpâkan êh-ayîtisinamiyit, ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamâyit awiyah, itêh kâ-wîkicik êkotê isi êy-is-îtâpiyit.
sentences.text: ê-kîsi-âmaciwêyit êkota pimisiniyiwa kâ-wâpamât itâpâkan ê-ayîtisinamiyit ê-wî-kakwê-wâpamâyit awiya itê kâ-wîkicik êkotê isi ê-isi-itâpiyit
sentences.english: When he had reached the summit, there he lay, and he saw him turning a spy-glass this way and that, trying to get sight of someone, as he kept looking out in the direction where the Assiniboine were encamped.

sentences.original: mâka namoya nôkwaniyiwa mîkiwâhpah, awasâyihk êh-wîkiwiht.
sentences.text: mâka namôya nôkwaniyiwa mîkiwâhpa awasâyihk ê-wîkiwiht
sentences.english: But the tipis were not visible, for they were camping behind a rise in the land.
At last he had watched him a long time.
Presently he saw him lower his head and no longer look about.
“Doubtless he is sleeping,” he thought, and started to walk in that direction.
He kept walking along where the other had climbed to the hilltop.

sentences.original: mâskôc ayahciyiniw, âhpôh êtokê opwâsimôw, itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “Probably he is a Blackfoot, and yet for all I know, he may be an Assiniboine,” he thought.
When he came to where the other had squatted down, he could see him lying with lowered head.
He could not tell who he was.
He could not see his face.

sentences.original: êkwah pêyâhtik pimohtêw, mâskôc pêkopayicih, nika-nipahik, ê-ytêyihtahk.
sentences.english: He walked carefully, thinking, “If by chance he should wake up, he would kill me.”
At last he got near to him.
When he looked at him, he saw that he was sound asleep and snoring.
At last he came right up to him.

sentences.original: êh-kitâpamât, êkotah pâskisikan astêyiw êkwah itâpâkan.
sentences.text: ê-kitâpamât êkota pâskisikan astêyiw êkwa itâpâkan
sentences.english: When he looked at him, there lay a gun and a spy-glass.
And he saw that he had extra moccasins tied in his belt.

sentences.original: êh-kitâpamât, ocihciyiwah ômis îsi êh-nipâyit, êh-aspiskwêsimot ocihciyah, kâ-wâpahtahk êh-kâh-kîskicihcêyit.
sentences.text: ê-kitâpamât ocihcîyiwa ômisi isi ê-nipâyit kâ-wâpahtahk ê-kâh-kîskicihcêyit
sentences.english: When he looked at him, as he slept there with his hands like this, “He is resting his head on his hands,” he thought, and then he saw that he had some fingers cut off.
He concluded, “And so he is a Blackfoot.”
He looked about him and saw a stone.
He walked back and took the stone.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-itohtêt itah kâ-nîpawiyit, êh-nahikâpawistawât, ostikwâniyihk êh-pakamahwât asiniyah ohci, nipahêw.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-itohtêt ita kâ-nîpawiyit ê-nahikâpawistawât ostikwâniyihk ê-pakamahwât asiniya ohci nipahêw
sentences.english: Then he went there where the other had stood, and took a good footing close to him, and hit him on the head with the stone, and killed him.

sentences.original: êkosi pâskisikan otinam, mîna itâpâkan, oskotâkayiw, omaskisiniyiwa, otâsiyiwa, mîna kaskitêw, mîna môsw-asiniyah.
sentences.text: êkosi pâskisikan otinam mîna itâpâkan oskotâkayiyiw omaskisiniyiwa otâsiyiwa mîna kaskitêw mîna môsw-asiniya
sentences.english: hen he took the gun, the spy-glass, his coat, his moccasins, his leggings, and the powder and bullets.
Then he went home.

sentences.original: êkâ h-nisitawêyimât, mâskôc ahpôh nêhiyaw nipisci-nipahâw, êh-itêyihtahk, êkâ k-ôh-manisamwât wêstakayiwa.
sentences.text: êkâ ê-nisitawêyimât ê-itêyihtahk êkâ kâ-ôh-manisamwât wêstakayiwa
sentences.english: Because he did not know who the other was, and thought, “Perhaps I have by mistake slain a Cree,” was why he did not cut off the other's scalp.
So he went home.
It was almost noon;
he had been too long killing that man.

sentences.original: êkoyikohk kêkâc êh-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik, takohtêw wîkiwâhk, êkwah êh-âcimot ôma, k-êsi-wâpamât ayîsiyiniwa, asiniyah ohci êh-pakamahwât.
sentences.text: êkoyikohk kêkâc ê-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik takohtêw wîkiwâhk êkwa ê-âcimot ôma kâ-isi-wâpamât ayîsiyiniwa asiniya ohci ê-pakamahwât
sentences.english: When it was almost noon, he reached their camp, and then he told of how he had seen a man and killed him with a stone.
I killed him while he slept.
These things which I am bringing are his possessions.
Because I thought of him, 'perhaps he is Cree,' is why I did not take his scalp,” he said.

sentences.original: ê-kiskinôhahk anim ispatinâw, ispayiwak êh-têhtapicik kotakak nâpêwak.
sentences.text: ê-kiskinôhahk anima ispatinâw ispayiwak ê-têhtapicik kotakak nâpêwak
sentences.english: When he had pointed out that hill, other men mounted and rode there.
When they saw him, they recognized him as a Blackfoot.
These men now cut off his scalp and took it home.

sentences.original: êh-takohtêcik, êkoyikohk êkwah miywêyihtamwak opwâsîmôwak, êkwah êh-nîmihitocik, êh-miyawâtahkik ê-nipahâcik ayahciyiniwah.
sentences.text: ê-takohtêcik êkoyikohk êkwa miywêyihtamwak opwâsîmôwak êkwa ê-nîmihitocik ê-miyawâtahkik ê-nipahâcik ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: When they arrived, the Assiniboine were glad, and danced, rejoicing because they had killed a Blackfoot.
So much for this.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê ntawih-sipwêhtêwak, êkwah aw âyahciyiniw itah kâ-pimisihk kâ-nipahiht, kîkwa têhtahêwak.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê nitawi-sipwêhtêwak êkwa awa ayahciyiniw ita kâ-pimisihk kâ-nipahiht kîkway têhtahêwak
sentences.english: Presently they set out for that place, and where that Blackfoot lay who had been slain, they put him up on something.

sentences.original: êkwah ôma itah kâ-kê-pimisihk asiskiy êh-manisahkik, tâpiskôc ayîsiyiniw êh-pimisihk êkosi êh-isi-manisahkik;
sentences.text: êkwa ôma ita kâ-kî-pimisihk asiskiy ê-manisahkik tâpiskôc ayîsiyiniw ê-pimisihk êkosi ê-isi-manisahkik
sentences.english: Then they cut away some of the ground where he had lain, cutting it like a man lying there;

sentences.original: êkwah aw ôpwâsimôw itah k-ôh-wâpamât ôh âyahciyiniwa, êkotah mînah asiskiy êh-ati-manisahkik, tâpiskôc itah êh-pimohtêt ayîsiyiniw êy-isi-manisahkik asiskiy.
sentences.text: êkwa awa opwâsîmôw ita kâ-ôh-wâpamât ôhi ayahciyiniwa êkota mîna asiskiy ê-ati-manisahkik tâpiskôc ita ê-pimohtêt ayîsiyiniw ê-isi-manisahkik asiskiy
sentences.english: and there whence that Assiniboine had seen that Blackfoot, there too they went cutting the ground, carving it out like a man walking.

sentences.original: itah mînah êh-ati-nakît mâna, êkotah ê-manisahkik asiskiy, piyisk êh-otihtât ôh ayahciyiniwah.
sentences.text: ita mîna ê-ati-nakît mâna êkota ê-manisahkik asiskiy piyisk ê-otihtât ôhi ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: And there where he had stopped on his way, they cut the ground, and finally where he had reached the Blackfoot.

sentences.original: êkwah mîna asiniyah k-ôtinât, êkotah mîna êh-manisahkik asiskiy.
sentences.text: êkwa mîna asiniya kâ-otinât êkota mîna ê-manisahkik asiskiy
sentences.english: And where he had taken the stone, there too they carved out the ground.

sentences.original: itah êh-tahkoskêt, êkwah mîna itah êh-nîpawit, ôh êh-pakamahwât ayahciyiniwa, êkosi êy-isi-kiskinawâcihtâcik.
sentences.text: ita ê-tahkoskêt êkwa mîna ita ê-nîpawit ôhi ê-pakamahwât ayahciyiniwa êkosi ê-isi-kiskinawâcihtâcik
sentences.english: Where he stepped, and also where he stood as he killed the Blackfoot, even so they marked it.

sentences.original: ôh ayahciyiniwah itah kâh-pimisiniyit, itah êh-itiskwêsihk itah kâ-masinahikâsot, êkotah êh-ahâcik ôh âsiniyah.
sentences.text: ôhi ayahciyiniwa ita kâ-pimisiniyit ita ê-itiskwêsihk ita kâ-masinahikâsot êkota ê-ahâcik ôhi asiniya
sentences.english: Where the Blackfoot had lain, there where the head of the image lay, there they placed that boulder.

sentences.original: mâmaskâc êkwoyâk êy-isi-wâpahtahkik ôh îyahciyiniwah, êh-nipâyit, ê-mosci-pakamahomiht asiniyah ohci.
sentences.text: mâmaskâc êkwêyâk ê-isi-wâpahtahkik ôhi ayahciyiniwa ê-nipâyit ê-mosci-pakamahomiht asiniya ohci
sentences.english: It wonderfully resembled their actual experience, the sleeping Blackfoot being struck by a stone held in the hand.

sentences.original: êkô ohci k-ôh-masinahwâcik, kinwêsk ta-nôkwan, êh-itêyihtahkik.
sentences.english: The reason they made the image of him was that they thought, “For a long time let it be visible.”
And truly, for a long time this thing was to be seen.
This is the end of the story.
